poor.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: having very little money and not many possessions
poor.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Her family were so poor they couldn’t afford to buy her new clothes.
an area where poor people lived
one of the poorest countries in the world
a poor part of Chicago  (=where a lot of poor people live)
My grandparents grew up dirt poor (=very poor).
Many of the families are desperately poor.
poor.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: It’s the government’s responsibility to help the poor.
tax relief for the working poor
poor.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: not as good as it could be or should be
poor.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The soil in this area is very poor.
He blames himself for the team’s poor performance.
The jacket was of very poor quality.
Her hearing is poor, so speak fairly loudly.
The builders did a really poor job of fixing our roof.
make/do a poor job of doing something
poor.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: used to show sympathy for someone because they are so unlucky, unhappy etc
poor.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Poor kid, he’s had a rough day.
You poor thing, you’ve had a hard time of it, haven’t you?
Poor old Ted was sick for weeks.
poor.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: someone whose health is poor is ill or weak for a long period of time
poor.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: My parents are both in rather poor health.
poor.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: Half the population remains desperately poor.
We were dirt poor back then.
Difficult economic conditions have driven millions of the rural poor to cities.
The condition of the urban poor could no longer be ignored.
These tax-cut proposals are targeted at the working poor.
poor.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: having very little money and not many possessions – used about people or places
Many families were too poor to pay for education.
poor countries
hard up/broke
having very little money, especially for a short period of time. Skint is more informal than the other words
I’m a bit hard up at the moment
We were so broke we couldn’t afford to go out to the cinema.
developing
a developing country is poor and has very little industry
The disease is found mainly in developing countries.
the developing world
deprived
much poorer than other people in a country, and not having the things that are necessary for a comfortable or happy life – used about people and areas
The charity works with deprived children in the inner city.
one of the most deprived areas of London
disadvantaged
used about groups of people in society who have much less chance of being successful because they are poor
An increase in the minimum wage would help the most disadvantaged Americans.
needy
having very little money, and so needing help – used about groups of people
More help should be given to needy families.
We offer scholarships for needy students.
destitute
having no money or possessions and nowhere to live – used when someone is in a very bad situation
Her family was left destitute after her father died.
destitute refugees
impoverished
impoverished people and places are very poor
out-of-work miners and their impoverished families
The children come from impoverished neighbourhoods.
one of the world’s most impoverished countries
poverty-stricken
extremely poor
poverty-stricken areas
They were left poverty-stricken.
penniless
having no money
She died penniless.
a penniless student
